title: Cartierheide
text:
Cartierheide is a natural landscape area in the south of the <a href="Netherlands">Netherlands</a> in province <a href="North%20Brabant">North Brabant</a> located close to the <a href="Belgium">Belgian</a> border in the natural region called The <a href="Campine">Campine</a> (local name in Dutch: De Kempen).
On the other side of the border is Belgium's first national park, <a href="Hoge%20Kempen%20National%20Park">Hoge Kempen</a>.
History.
The name is derived from Baron Emile de Cartier Marchiennes who purchased it in 1863, the moor near this location <a href="Duizel">Duizel</a>s Hof and used the heath as hunting grounds.
Heide is a Dutch word for <a href="heath">heath</a> or heathland which is a shrubland habitat found mainly on low quality acidic soils, and is characterised by open, low growing woody vegetation.
The property was given to the Dutch Society for preservation of nature monuments <a href="Natuurmonumenten">Natuurmonumenten</a> in 1932 by the son of Baron de Cartier who was also named <a href="Emile%20de%20Cartier%20de%20Marchienne">Emile de Cartier de Marchienne</a> and put under management of <a href="Staatsbosbeheer">Staatsbosbeheer</a> a Dutch organization to control and conserve Dutch nature reserves. 
There are several touristic sight seeing and walking routes from surrounding villages like <a href="Bergeijk">Bergeijk</a>, VVV <a href="Eersel">Eersel</a> and protected and maintained by AVN Kempenland
